us-bibliographic-data-application.invention-title: MEDICAL OBSERVATION SYSTEM, APPARATUS, CONTROL METHOD, AND IMAGING APPARATUS

abstract.p: A light emitting device irradiates a surgical area with first wavelength light and second wavelength light. A wobbling operation of a focus lens included in an imaging device is controlled according to an emission timing of the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light when the surgical area is alternately irradiated with the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light. The present disclosure can be applied to an endoscopic surgical system, for example.

description.heading: TECHNICAL FIELD
description.p: The present disclosure relates to a medical observation system, a control apparatus, a control method, and an imaging apparatus, and particularly, to a medical observation system, a control apparatus, a control method, and an imaging apparatus that enable more accurate AF to be realized.
description.heading: BACKGROUND ART
description.p: Generally, in medical observation apparatuses such as a surgical endoscope and a surgical microscope, since the depth of field is shallow but the surgical field is deep, so the region to be visually recognized is not focused.
In contrast, medical observation apparatuses having an AF (Auto Focus) function that automatically focuses is proposed.

For example, PTL 1 discloses a medical observation system that obtains a deep-focus image with a low delay and a high frame rate by photographing while changing the focus position. Moreover, PTL 2 discloses a focus control apparatus that performs focus control using wobbling.

Patent Literature
SUMMARY OF INVENTION
Technical Problem
description.p: In an imaging apparatus having the AF function, as disclosed in PTL 2, in order to determine a direction in which a focus lens is moved to an in-focus position, an operation called wobbling that slightly moves the focus lens back and forth is often performed. With the wobbling operation, an AF evaluation value for evaluating an in-focus state can be obtained.
On the other hand, in a medical observation apparatus, a living tissue serving as a subject may be observed by alternately irradiating with normal light and special light.

However, when normal light and special light are alternately irradiated in the middle of a wobbling operation, there is a possibility that an appropriate AF evaluation value is not obtained. As a result, there is a possibility that highly accurate AF is not realized.
The present disclosure has been made in view of the above-described problems and enables more accurate AF to be realized.
description.heading: Solution to Problem
description.p: A medical observation system according to a first aspect of the present disclosure is a medical observation system comprising: a non-transitory computer medium including computer program instructions, which when executed by circuitry, cause the circuitry to control a light emitting device configured to irradiate a surgical area with first wavelength light and second wavelength light; control an imaging device configured to capture an image of the surgical area; and control a wobbling operation of a focus lens included in the imaging device according to an emission timing of the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light when the surgical area is alternately irradiated with the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light.

An apparatus according to a first aspect of the present disclosure is an apparatus comprising: circuitry configured to obtain a plurality of images captured by an imaging device during a period of time during which a first wavelength light and a second wavelength light are alternately irradiated; determine auto-focus evaluation values of at least a first image and a second image each captured by receiving reflected light of the first wavelength light, wherein the first image and the second image are captured with a focus lens of the imaging device in different positions; and determine a movement amount and movement direction of the focus lens by comparing the auto-focus evaluation values of the at least the first image and the second image.

A medical observation method according to a first aspect of the present disclosure is a medical observation method performed by a medical observation system including a light emitting device that irradiates a surgical area with first wavelength light and second wavelength light, and circuitry configured to control an imaging device that captures an image of the surgical area, the method comprising: controlling a wobbling operation of a focus lens included in the imaging device according to an emission timing of the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light when the surgical area is alternately irradiated with the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light.

An imaging apparatus according to a second aspect of the present disclosure is an imaging apparatus comprising: a light emitting device that irradiates a subject with first wavelength light and second wavelength light; and circuitry configured to control an imaging device that captures an image of the subject, wherein in a wobbling operation of a focus lens included in the imaging device, the circuitry performs control to not move the focus lens at least during an emission period in which the light emitting unit emits the first wavelength light.

In the first aspect of the present disclosure, the surgical area is irradiated with the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light, the imaging unit that captures an image of the surgical area is controlled, and when the surgical area is alternately irradiated with the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light, the wobbling operation of the focus lens included in the imaging unit is controlled according to an emission timing of the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light.

In the second aspect of the present disclosure, the subject is irradiated with the first wavelength light and the second wavelength light, the imaging unit that captures an image of the subject is controlled, and in the wobbling operation of the focus lens included in the imaging unit, the focus lens is not moved at least during the emission period in which the light emitting unit emits the first wavelength light.

description.heading: 1. System Configuration
description.p: (Configuration Example of Medical Observation System)
FIG. 1 is a diagram illustrating a configuration example of a medical observation system according to the present embodiment.
FIG. 1 illustrates an example of an endoscopic surgical system used in abdominal endoscopic surgery performed in place of conventional open surgery in a medical field.

A medical observation system 1 includes an inserting portion 11, a light source apparatus 12, a light guide 13, a camera head (an imaging unit) 14, a first transmission cable 15, a display apparatus 16, a second transmission cable 17, a control apparatus 18, a third transmission cable 19, a connector 20, and a connector 21. The combination of the inserting portion 11 and the camera head 14 may be referred to as an endoscope. The endoscope may also include at least one of the inserting portion 11, the light source apparatus 12, the light guide 13, the first transmission cable 15, the display apparatus 16, the second transmission cable 17, the control apparatus 18, the third transmission cable 19, the connector 20 and the connector 21.

The inserting portion 11 is configured as a rigid mirror or a flexible mirror (for example, a fiberscope), for example. The inserting portion 11 is a member that is hard or at least partially soft, has an elongated shape, and is inserted into a living body. An optical system that includes one or a plurality of lenses and condenses a subject image is provided in the inserting portion 11. The inserting portion 11 and the camera head 14 may be integrated.

One end of the light guide 13 is connected to the light source apparatus 12. The light source apparatus 12 supplies light for illuminating the inside of the living body to one end of the light guide 13 under the control of the control apparatus 18.

The light guide 13 has one end detachably attached to the light source apparatus 12 and has the other end detachably attached to the inserting portion 11. The light guide 13 transmits the light supplied from the light source apparatus 12 to one end to the other end to supply the light to the inserting portion 11. The light supplied to the inserting portion 11 is emitted from a tip of the inserting portion 11 to the inside of the living body. Light (subject image) emitted to the living body and reflected from the inside of the living body is condensed by the optical system in the inserting portion 11.

The camera head 14 is detachably connected to an eyepiece portion 11A which is a proximal end of the inserting portion 11. The camera head 14 captures the subject image condensed by the inserting portion 11 and outputs image data (RAW data) under the control of the control apparatus 18. The image data is image data of 4K or more, for example.
Hereinafter, an image based on the image data is also referred to as a captured image.

The first transmission cable 15 has one end detachably connected to the control apparatus 18 via the connector 20 and has the other end detachably connected to the camera head 14 via the connector 21. The first transmission cable 15 transmits image data and the like output from the camera head 14 to the control apparatus 18 and transmits a control signal, a synchronization signal, a clock signal, and an electric power output from the control apparatus 18 to the camera head 14. A memory may be mounted on, or included in, the connector 20 or the connector 21, and parameters related to the camera head 14 and the control apparatus 18 may be stored in the memory. For example, the factory parameters of the camera head 14 and the parameters changed when the power is turned on may be stored in the memory, and the operation of the camera head may be changed based on the parameters read from the memory.

The image data and the like transmitted from the camera head 14 to the control apparatus 18 via the first transmission cable 15 may be an optical signal or an electrical signal. The same applies to transmission of the control signal, the synchronization signal, and the clock signal from the control apparatus 18 to the camera head 14 via the first transmission cable 15.
The display apparatus 16 displays a display image based on a video signal output from the control apparatus 18 under the control of the control apparatus 18.

The second transmission cable 17 has one end detachably connected to the display apparatus 16 and has the other end detachably connected to the control apparatus 18. The second transmission cable 17 transmits a video signal processed by the control apparatus 18 and a control signal output from the control apparatus 18 to the display apparatus 16.

The control apparatus 18 is configured as a camera control unit (CCU), for example, and includes a circuit including a CPU (Central Processing Unit) and the like. The control apparatus 18 integrally controls the operations of the light source apparatus 12, the camera head 14, and the display apparatus 16.

The third transmission cable 19 has one end detachably connected to the light source apparatus 12 and has the other end detachably connected to the control apparatus 18. The third transmission cable 19 transmits the control signal from the control apparatus 18 to the light source apparatus 12.
(Configuration Example of Camera Head and Control Apparatus)
Next, a configuration example of the camera head 14 and the control apparatus 18 will be described with reference to FIG. 2.
The camera head 14 includes a lens unit 31, a lens driving unit 32, and an imaging processing unit 33.

The lens unit 31 includes a plurality of lenses movable along an optical axis and forms a subject image condensed by the inserting portion 11 on an imaging surface of the imaging processing unit 33. The lens unit 31 includes a focus lens 41 and a zoom lens 42.
The focus lens 41 includes one or a plurality of lenses and adjusts the focus of the camera head 14 by moving along the optical axis.
The zoom lens 42 includes one or a plurality of lenses and adjusts the angle of view of the camera head 14 by moving along the optical axis.

Although not illustrated in the drawing, the lens unit 31 includes a focus mechanism that moves the focus lens 41 along the optical axis and an optical zoom mechanism that moves the zoom lens 42 along the optical axis.

The lens driving unit 32 includes an actuator that operates the focus mechanism and the optical zoom mechanism and a driver that drives the actuator. The lens driving unit 32 adjusts the focus and the angle of view of the lens unit 31 under the control of the control apparatus 18.

The lens driving unit 32 includes a position sensor such as a photo interrupter. The lens driving unit 32 detects the position of the focus lens 41 and the position of the zoom lens 42 and outputs a detection signal corresponding to these positions to the control apparatus 18.

The imaging processing unit 33 includes a sensor chip in which an imaging element and a signal processing unit are formed integrally. The imaging element is configured, for example, as CCD (Charge Coupled Device) or CMOS (Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor) and converts the subject image condensed by the inserting portion 11 and formed by the lens unit 31 and converts the same to an electrical signal. The imaging processing unit 33 performs signal processing such as A/D conversion on the electrical signal (analog signal) from the imaging element and outputs image data. The imaging processing unit 33 captures an image of the inside of the living body and outputs image data (digital data) after A/D conversion under the control of the control apparatus 18.

The imaging processing unit 33 may not be formed integrally with the imaging element but may be a separate unit. Moreover, the imaging element preferably has a number of pixels capable of outputting image data of a resolution of 4K (3840×2160 pixels) or more.
The control apparatus 18 includes a signal processing unit 51, a control unit 52, an input unit 53, an output unit 54, and a storage unit 55.
The signal processing unit 51 performs various kinds of processing on the image data (RAW data) output from the camera head 14 under the control of the control unit 52.

The signal processing unit 51 performs RAW processing such as optical black subtraction processing and demosaic processing on the image data (RAW data) to convert the same to RGB data. Moreover, the signal processing unit 51 performs RGB processing such as white balancing, RGB gamma correction, and YC conversion on the obtained RGB data. Furthermore, the signal processing unit 51 executes YC processing such as color difference correction and noise reduction on the obtained Y and Cb/Cr data. The signal processing unit 51 supplies the image data after the image processing to the control unit 52.

The signal processing unit 51 calculates an evaluation value for controlling the camera head 14 with respect to the image data (for example, Y and Cb/Cr data) after the image processing. For example, the signal processing unit 51 detects the contrast and the frequency component of an image in a designated region on the basis of pixel information (luminance data (Y)) of each pixel of the designated region in one frame of captured images captured by the imaging processing unit 33. The signal processing unit 51 calculates an in-focus evaluation value (AF evaluation value) for evaluating an in-focus state of the captured image (a subject image therein) on the basis of the detected contrast and frequency component and supplies the calculated evaluation value to the control unit 52.

The control unit 52 is configured as a CPU or the like, for example, and controls the operations of the light source apparatus 12, the camera head 14, and the display apparatus 16 and controls the overall operation of the control apparatus 18 by outputting a control signal. The control unit 52 includes a focus control unit 61, an emission control unit 62, and a display control unit 63.

The focus control unit 61 adjusts the focus of the lens unit 31 (changes the position of the focus lens 41) by operating the lens driving unit 32. For example, the focus control unit 61 executes evaluation processing on the basis of the position of the focus lens 41 detected by the lens driving unit 32 and the AF evaluation value from the signal processing unit 51. Moreover, the focus control unit 61 controls an AF operation of the focus lens 41 on the basis of operation information from the input unit 53.

The emission control unit 62 controls emission of a light emitting unit 71 included in the light source apparatus 12. The light emitting unit 71 emits light to irradiate a surgical area serving as a subject with normal light such as WLI (White Light Imaging) light (for example, visible light including light having a wavelength band of 360 nm to 760 nm) as light having a first wavelength band (first wavelength light) and special light such as IR (Infrared) light as light having a second wavelength band (second wavelength light). Here, IR light may include NIR (Near-infrared) light. For example, IR light may be light having a wavelength band of 760 nm or more and 1000 μm or smaller.

The display control unit 63 generates a display video signal on the basis of the image data (Y and Cb/Cr data) processed by the signal processing unit 51 by OSD (On Screen Display) processing or the like and outputs the video signal to the display apparatus 16.

The input unit 53 includes an operating device such as buttons, switches, a mouse, a keyboard, and a touch panel and receives a user's operation. The input unit 53 supplies an input signal input by the user's operation to the control unit 52.
The output unit 54 includes a speaker, a printer, and the like and outputs various kinds of information.
The storage unit 55 stores programs executed by the control unit 52 and information and the like necessary for processing of the control unit 52.

The display apparatus 16 include a display device which uses liquid crystal or organic EL (Electro Luminescence) and displays a display image based on the video signal output from the control apparatus 18.
(Control of AF Function)
In the medical observation system 1, three modes including a one-touch AF mode, a continuous AF mode, and a manual mode, for example, are realized as a focus adjustment mode.
The one-touch AF mode is a mode in which AF is performed sporadically according to an operation on an operating unit (not illustrated) provided in the camera head 14, for example.

The continuous AF mode is a mode in which AF is basically performed always (continuously). For example, the continuous AF mode is a mode in which AF is performed when evaluation of a captured image is performed continuously and an obtained evaluation value satisfies a predetermined condition. The continuous AF mode is switched on and off according to an operation on the input unit 53, for example.
The manual mode is a mode in which a user moves the focus lens 41 according to an operation on the input unit 53, for example.
In the one-touch AF mode and the continuous AF mode, similar processing is performed until the movement amount of the focus lens 41 is determined.

Here, an AF function control method will be described. As the AF function control method, for example, a method (so-called hill-climbing AF method) of calculating an AF evaluation value of a captured image and adjusting the position of the focus lens 41 so that the AF evaluation value becomes the highest is the mainstream.

The AF evaluation value of the position of the focus lens 41 is maximized at an in-focus position. Therefore, AF can be realized by controlling the position of the focus lens 41 so that the AF evaluation value is maximized. Furthermore, a wobbling operation is performed to determine the movement amount and the direction of moving the focus lens 41 to the in-focus position.

As illustrated in FIG. 3, regarding the focus lens 41, movement to the in-focus position according to the hill-climbing AF method and a wobbling operation are performed. In FIG. 3, the horizontal axis indicates time and the vertical axis indicates the position of the focus lens 41. The control of the timing to acquire the AF evaluation value and the movement of lenses, and the driving instruction are executed with reference to a vertical synchronization signal (for example, a timing corresponding to one field or one frame). In this example, it is assumed that the control and the instruction are executed with reference to the timing corresponding to one frame.

In a wobbling operation, first, the focus lens 41 is moved by a certain distance in a direction away from the imaging element in a first period, and the focus lens is stopped for a certain period of time in a second period. Moreover, the focus lens is moved by a certain distance in a direction closer to the imaging element in a third period, and the focus lens is stopped for a certain period of time in a fourth period. A series of these operations from the first to fourth periods is performed repeatedly. The period from the first to fourth periods (regardless of the order) is regarded as one cycle of wobbling.

The AF evaluation values in the second and fourth periods are detected and the difference is calculated whereby a fluctuation component of the AF evaluation value due to the wobbling operation can be obtained. By determining the sign (positive/negative) of the fluctuation component, the direction and the movement amount of moving the focus lens 41 to the in-focus position is determined.

In surgical endoscopes and surgical microscopes, an observation method called special light observation is known. Special light observation is an observation method in which normal light such as WLI light and special light such as IR light are irradiated alternately to obtain an image that cannot be obtained with normal light only.
FIG. 4 is a diagram for comparing an image obtained by normal light observation and an image obtained by special light observation.

FIG. 4A illustrates a WLI image obtained by irradiating WLI light only and FIG. 4B illustrates a superimposed image in which an IR image obtained by irradiating an IR light is superimposed on the WLI image. Since the IR image is a luminance image composed of luminance data, the IR image highlighted in a pseudo color is superimposed on the WLI image.

As illustrated in FIG. 4, in special light observation using IR light, ICG (indocyanate green) administered to a living tissue serving as a subject is excited by IR light to generate fluorescence, and the deep part of a blood vessel is highlighted by a luminance image obtained by receiving the fluorescence.

In special light observation, when WLI light and IR light is irradiated alternately, the AF evaluation value of the IR image as well as the AF evaluation value of the WLI image is calculated by the above-described AF function.

However, since an IR image tends to be an unclear luminance image, it is not appropriate to use the AF evaluation value of the IR image to determine the movement amount and the direction of moving the focus lens 41 by the wobbling operation.

Therefore, in the medical observation system according to the present embodiment, a wobbling operation of the focus lens 41 is controlled according to an emission timing of normal light (WLI light) and special light (IR light).
description.heading: 2. Example of Wobbling Operation
description.p: An example of a wobbling operation of the focus lens 41 according to an emission timing of WLI light and IR light in the medical observation system 1 will be described with reference to FIG. 5.

FIG. 5 illustrates the timings of a vertical synchronization signal, emission (IR emission) of IR light, emission (WLI emission) of WLI light, exposure, and a wobbling operation of the focus lens 41. Although movement of the focus lens 41 according to the hill-climbing AF method as well as a wobbling operation is also illustrated in FIG. 3, only the wobbling operation is illustrated in FIG. 5.

As illustrated in FIG. 5, the control unit 52 (the emission control unit 62) controls the light emitting unit 71 so that WLI light and IR light are alternately emitted in synchronization with a vertical synchronization signal. In the example of FIG. 5, the light emitting unit 71 emits WLI light or IR light in the period of the latter half (0.5) cycle of one cycle of the vertical synchronization signal.

As illustrated in FIG. 5, exposure (readout) corresponding to an emission period of the WLI light and exposure (readout) corresponding to an emission period of the IR light are performed alternately. In this way, the WLI image and the IR image are captured alternately.

As illustrated in FIG. 5, a switching timing of the exposure corresponding to the emission period of the WLI light and the exposure corresponding to the emission period of the IR light is synchronized with a switching timing of a moving period and a stopping period of the focus lens 41 in the wobbling operation.

In other words, the emission period of the WLI light and the emission period of the IR light are synchronized with the moving period and the stopping period of the focus lens 41 in the wobbling operation. In this case, the control unit 52 (the focus control unit 61) controls the wobbling operation of the focus lens 41 according to the emission timings of the WLI light and the IR light. More specifically, the focus control unit 61 does not move the focus lens 41 in the wobbling operation at least during the emission period of the WLI light and moves the focus lens 41 in the wobbling operation at least during the emission period of the IR light.

The evaluation process (determination of the direction and the movement amount of the focus lens 41) using the AF evaluation value is performed in the stopping period (the exposure period of the WLI image) of the focus lens 41 in the wobbling operation and the result thereof is used in the subsequent movement of the focus lens 41. In the evaluation process, the AF evaluation value calculated from the WLI image captured in the previous stopping period in the wobbling operation and the AF evaluation value calculated from the WLI image captured in a stopping period before the previous stopping period are acquired. In the evaluation process using the AF evaluation value, an AF evaluation value calculated from at least two WLI images may be acquired. The focus control unit 61 may perform control so that the focus lens 41 is not moved in the wobbling operation at least during an exposure period of pixels for receiving a WLI light and calculating an AF evaluation value. For example, when the pixels for calculating the AF evaluation value used in the wobbling operation are pixels positioned near the center of an imaging element, the focus lens 41 is not moved in a period in which the pixels positioned around the center are exposed to the WLI light, and the focus lens 41 is moved in a period in which the other pixels are exposed to the WLI light. In this way, by moving the focus lens in an exposure period of an invalid region of an endoscope image which becomes dark due to vignetting resulting from the scope, it is possible to secure a longer moving time of the focus lens.

According to the above-described operation, the focus lens 41 is moved in the wobbling operation in an exposure period (an emission period of the IR light) of an IR image that is not used for calculation of the AF evaluation value. That is, since the focus lens 41 is not moved during capturing of a WLI image in the wobbling operation, the focus shake can be reduced and an evaluation process (determination of the direction and the movement amount of the focus lens 41) using the AF evaluation value calculated from two clear WLI images can be performed. In other words, the movement amount and direction of the focus lens 41 are calculated by comparing the AF evaluation values of the two WLI images.

In this way, even when a wobbling operation is performed in special light observation in which normal light such as WLI light and special light such as IR light are irradiated alternately, it is possible to obtain an appropriate AF evaluation value and realize more accurate AF.

As described above, although an IR image is captured so as to correspond to an emission period of IR light, an AF evaluation value is not calculated from the IR image. However, the AF evaluation value calculated from the IR image is not used in the evaluation process even if the AF evaluation value is not stored in the storage unit 55 of the control apparatus 18 or is stored in the storage unit 55. If the difference between the two AF evaluation values is larger than a predetermined value, the wobbling operation may be reset. As a result, it is possible to reset the AF evaluation value when the AF evaluation value of the WLI image and the IR image is compared due to error (for example, a synchronization error).

In the wobbling operation of the medical observation system 1 according to the present embodiment, as illustrated in FIG. 5, the focus lens 41 is moved in the wobbling operation with reference to the center of balance of the exposure period corresponding to a WLI light. Specifically, a midpoint (the center of balance of an exposure period corresponding to IR light) between the centers of balance of two successive exposure periods (exposure periods used for calculation of the AF evaluation value) corresponding to WLI light coincides with a midpoint of the moving time of the focus lens 41 in the wobbling operation. The center of balance of an exposure period may be regarded as an exposure time of pixels positioned at the center of an imaging element.

In this way, in the evaluation process of the wobbling operation, when the AF evaluation values calculated from two WLI images are compared, it is possible to equalize the respective AF evaluation values.

As described above with reference to FIG. 3, although movement of the focus lens 41 to the in-focus position by the hill-climbing AF method as well as the wobbling operation of the focus lens 41 is controlled, the movement of the focus lens 41 may be stopped completely during the emission period of the WLI light. In this way, the rolling shutter distortion in the WLI image can be reduced.
description.heading: 3. Modified Example
description.p: (Special Light Observation Mode and Normal Light Observation Mode)

The medical observation system according to the present embodiment can operate in a normal light observation mode in which a surgical area serving as a subject is irradiated with normal light only in addition to a special light observation mode in which the surgical area is alternately irradiated with normal light and special light. In the normal light observation mode, a wobbling operation is performed regardless of an emission timing or the like.

In this case, the movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be different from the special light observation mode and the normal light observation mode. Moreover, the movement amount of the focus lens in the hill-climbing AF operation may be different from the special light observation mode to the normal light observation mode. Here, the movement amount being different means that the focus lens moves different distances.

For example, the movement amount of the focus lens during the emission period of IR light in the wobbling operation in the special light observation mode may be smaller than that in the normal light observation mode. A user may frequently switch from the normal light observation mode to the special light observation mode when a region to be observed is already in focus. Therefore, in the special light observation mode, it is not necessary to move the focus lens as much as in the normal light observation mode. Furthermore, by decreasing the amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation, it is possible to reduce the influence of image distortion due to the wobbling operation. Moreover, for example, the movement amount of the hill-climbing AF operation in the special light observation mode may be smaller than that in the normal light observation mode. Furthermore, in the special light observation mode, the movement amount of the hill-climbing AF operation during the emission period of second wavelength light may be smaller than the movement amount of the hill-climbing AF operation during the emission period of first wavelength light. In this way, it is possible to flexibly set the irradiation time of the second wavelength light and the imaging frame rate of the second wavelength light. Moreover, the movement amount of the focus lens during the emission period of IR light in the wobbling operation in the special light observation mode may be larger than that in the normal light observation mode. There is a possibility that a region to be observed by an operator may be different from the normal light observation mode to the special light observation mode. Therefore, by increasing the movement amount of the focus lens in the special light observation mode to be larger than that in the normal light observation mode, it is possible to focus on an observation target different from that of the normal light observation mode.

Since the focus in the special light observation is on the deeper side than the focus in the normal light observation, the focus lens in the wobbling operation in the special light observation mode may be moved closer to the FAR side (i.e., the side further away from the object under observation as viewed on an optical axis of the imaging device) than in the normal light observation mode. Similarly, a reference position of the focus lens in the wobbling operation in the special light observation mode may be moved closer to the FAR side than in the normal light observation mode.

The moving speed of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be different from the special light observation mode and the normal light observation mode. Moreover, the moving speed of the focus lens in the hill-climbing AF operation may be different from the special light observation mode and the normal light observation mode.

For example, the moving speed of the focus lens during the emission period of IR light in the wobbling operation in the special light observation mode may be higher than that in the normal light observation mode. In this way, when it is necessary to shorten the emission period of IR light, a sufficient wobbling operation can be performed. Moreover, for example, the moving speed of the hill-climbing AF operation in the special light observation mode may be higher than that in the normal light observation mode. In this way, it is possible to move the focus lens to the in-focus position more quickly while suppressing the influence on the evaluation value. Moreover, by increasing the movement amount during emission of normal light to be larger than during emission of IR light, it is possible to suppress the influence of a rolling shutter while suppressing increase in focusing time and acquire a more accurate evaluation value. Furthermore, in the special light observation mode, the moving speed in the hill-climbing AF operation during the emission period of second wavelength light may be higher than the moving speed in the hill-climbing AF operation during the emission period of first wavelength light. In this way, it is possible to flexibly set the irradiation time of the second wavelength light and the imaging frame rate of the second wavelength light.

As described above, when the movement amount and the moving speed of the focus lens in the wobbling operation are different from the special light observation mode and the normal light observation mode, the movement amount and the moving speed in the special light observation mode may be changed according to the irradiation time of the IR light to move the focus lens in the wobbling operation. Similarly, the movement amount and the moving speed in the special light observation mode may be changed according to the imaging frame rate to move the focus lens in the wobbling operation. In this way, in the special light observation mode, the irradiation time of the first wavelength light can be easily made different from that of the second wavelength light and the frame rate can be easily made different, and the degree of freedom in design can be improved.

When it is determined by image recognition that an organ serving as a surgical site is in focus, the movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be decreased. For the image recognition, for example, image recognition based on machine learning using a neural network can be used. In the above-described example, the movement amount of the focus lens is determined on the basis of at least two AF evaluation values. However, the movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be determined using machine learning. The machine learning parameters may be changed depending on a surgical form.

(Operation in the Event of Trouble)
When IR light emission stops:

When emission of IR light stops during movement of the focus lens in the wobbling operation, rather than stopping the focus lens on the spot, the focus lens may be moved by a specified movement amount and then be returned to the reference position. When the special light observation mode switches to the normal light observation mode, since the obtained captured image is slightly disturbed, the focus lens is returned to the reference position and is stopped for a period of time.
When fluctuation component of AF evaluation value is small:

When the fluctuation component of the AF evaluation value due to the wobbling operation is small, since there is a possibility that an evaluation process cannot be performed, the movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be increased. In this case, the focus lens may be moved in the wobbling operation during the emission period of WLI light as well as during the emission period of IR light.

(Operation Specialized for Endoscopic Surgical System)
Wobbling operation depending on model:

The movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be changed depending on a connected inserting portion (scope) or camera head. For example, a small-diameter scope used in otorhinology has a deeper depth of field than a large-diameter scope used in laparoscopic surgery. Therefore, in order to obtain a highly accurate AF evaluation value, the movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be increased. Moreover, when the control apparatus stores a plurality of modes according to a surgical form, the control apparatus may change the movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation according to the mode of the surgical form selected by the user. For example, when the surgical form includes an “arthroscopy mode”, a “cystoscopy mode”, an “otolaryngology/skull examination mode”, a “hysteroscopy mode”, and a “laparoscopic examination mode”, the movement amount of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be changed for each mode.
Wobbling operation according to diameter of inserting portion:

The number of movements of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be changed depending on the diameter of a connected inserting portion (scope) and a camera head. For example, a small-diameter scope used in otorhinology has a deeper depth of field than a large-diameter scope used in laparoscopic surgery. Therefore, in order to obtain a highly accurate AF evaluation value, the number of movements of the focus lens in the wobbling operation may be increased.
Wobbling operation according to insertion/removal of inserting portion:

The insertion/removal of the inserting portion (scope) may be detected, and the wobbling operation may be stopped when removal of the scope is detected during the wobbling operation. In this way, it is possible to prevent the actuator from being damaged by the removal movement. Moreover, it is preferable that the wobbling operation is not performed even when the scope is being removed.
Wobbling operation according to connection state of inserting portion:

The connection between the inserting portion (scope) and the camera head may be detected, and the wobbling operation may not be performed when connection of the scope is not detected due to replacement or the like of the scope.
(Wavelength Band of Light Emitted by Light Emitting Unit)

In the above-description, it is assumed that WLI light (normal light) is irradiated as the first wavelength light, and IR light (special light) is irradiated as the second wavelength light. However, there is no limitation thereto, and for example, blue light may be irradiated as the first wavelength light, and green light or ultraviolet light may be irradiated as the second wavelength light. Moreover, during the irradiation time of the second wavelength light, IR light and ultraviolet light may be irradiated simultaneously and the IR light and the ultraviolet light may be irradiated sequentially.
description.heading: 4. Application Example
description.p: (Surgical Video Microscope Apparatus)

Next, an example in which a surgical video microscope apparatus including an arm is used will be described as another application example of the medical observation system according to the present embodiment with reference to FIG. 6.
FIG. 6 illustrates an example of a microscopic surgical system which uses a surgical video microscope apparatus as an observation medical device for observing the inside of a patient.

FIG. 6 illustrates a state in which a physician who is an operator (user) 220 performs an operation on an operation target (patient) 240 on an operating table 230 using an operation instrument 221 such as, for example, a scalpel, tweezers, and forceps.

In the following description, the term “operation” refers to a general term for various medical treatments, such as surgery and examination, that the physician who is the user 220 performs on a patient who is the operation target 240. In the example of FIG. 6, although the situation of surgery is illustrated as an example of an operation, the operation used by the surgical video microscope apparatus 210 is not limited to surgery but may be various other operations.
The surgical video microscope apparatus 210 according to the present embodiment is provided beside the operating table 230.

The surgical video microscope apparatus 210 includes a base portion 211 as a base, an arm portion 212 extending from the base portion 211, and an imaging unit 215 connected to a tip of the arm portion 212 as a tip unit.

The arm portion 212 includes a plurality of joint portions 213a, 213b, and 213c, a plurality of links 214a and 214b connected by the joint portions 213a and 213b, and the imaging unit 215 provided at the tip of the arm portion 212.

In the example of FIG. 6, for simplicity, the arm portion 212 has three joint portions 213a to 213c and two links 214a and 214b. Practically, in consideration of the degree of freedom in the position and the posture of the arm portion 212 and the imaging unit 215, the numbers and the shapes of the joint portions 213a to 213c and the links 214a and 214b and the direction of the driving shaft of the joint portions 213a to 213c may be set appropriate so that a desired degree of freedom is realized.

The joint portions 213a to 213c have a function of rotatably connecting the links 214a and 214b, and the driving of the arm portion 212 is controlled by driving the rotation of the joint portions 213a to 213c.
The imaging unit 215 as a tip unit is connected to the tip of the arm portion 212.

The imaging unit 215 is a unit that acquires an imaging target image by including an optical system for acquiring an optical image of a subject and is configured as a camera or the like capable of capturing a moving image and a still image, for example. As illustrated in FIG. 6, the posture and the position of the arm portion 212 and the imaging unit 215 are controlled by the surgical video microscope apparatus 210 so that the imaging unit 215 provided at the tip of the arm portion 212 captures the image of the state of the operating region of the operation target 240.

The configuration of the imaging unit 215 connected to the distal end of the arm portion 212 as a tip unit is not particularly limited, and for example, the imaging unit 215 may be configured as an endoscope or a microscope. Moreover, the imaging unit 215 may be configured to be detachably attached to the arm portion 212.

With such a configuration, for example, an imaging unit 215 corresponding to the purpose of use may be appropriately connected to the tip of the arm portion 212 as a tip unit. Although a case in which the imaging unit 215 is applied as the tip unit will be described, the tip unit connected to the tip of the arm portion 212 is naturally not limited to the imaging unit 215.

A display apparatus 250 such as a monitor or a display is provided at a position facing the user 220. The image of the operating region acquired by the imaging unit 215 is processed by an image processing apparatus incorporated in or externally attached to the surgical video microscope apparatus 210, for example, and is displayed on the display screen of the display apparatus 250 as an electronic image.

With such a configuration, the user 220 can perform various treatments (for example, surgery or the like) while viewing the electronic image of the operating portion displayed on the display screen of the display apparatus 250.

Here, in the example of FIG. 6, the imaging unit 215 includes the camera head 14 and the light source apparatus 12 (the light emitting unit 71) described with reference to FIG. 2, for example. Moreover, the image processing apparatus that performs various kinds of image processing on the image of the operating region acquired by the imaging unit 215 corresponds to an example of the control apparatus described with reference to FIG. 2. Similarly, the display apparatus 250 corresponds to an example of the display apparatus 16 described with reference to FIG. 2.
(General Imaging System)
The technology according to the present disclosure is not limited to the medical observation system but can be applied to a general imaging system.
FIG. 7 illustrates a configuration example of an imaging apparatus which is an example of a general imaging system. An imaging apparatus 310 in FIG. 7 is configured as a consumer camera, for example.

The imaging apparatus 310 includes a lens unit 331, a lens driving unit 332, an imaging processing unit 333, a signal processing unit 351, a control unit 352, an input unit 353, an output unit 354, a storage unit 355, and a light emitting unit 356.

The lens unit 331, the lens driving unit 332, and the imaging processing unit 333 correspond to the lens unit 31, the lens driving unit 32, and the imaging processing unit 33 included in the camera head 14 illustrated in FIG. 2. That is, a focus lens 341 and a zoom lens 342 included in the lens unit 331 also correspond to the focus lens 41 and the zoom lens 42 included in the lens unit 31 illustrated in FIG. 2.

The signal processing unit 351, the control unit 352, the input unit 353, the output unit 354, and the storage unit 355 correspond to the signal processing unit 51, the control unit 52, the input unit 53, the output unit 54, and the storage unit 55 included in the control apparatus 18 illustrated in FIG. 2. That is, a focus control unit 361, an emission control unit 362, and a display control unit 363 included in the control unit 352 also correspond to the focus control unit 61, the emission control unit 62, and the display control unit 63 included in the control unit 52 illustrated in FIG. 2.
The light emitting unit 356 corresponds to the light emitting unit 71 included in the light source apparatus 12 illustrated in FIG. 2.

In the above-described configuration, even when a wobbling operation is performed in an observation mode in which first wavelength light (normal light) and second wavelength light (special light) are alternately irradiated, it is possible to obtain an appropriate AF evaluation value and realize more accurate AF.
description.heading: 5. Hardware Configuration
description.p: Next, an example of a hardware configuration of a control apparatus that constitutes the medical observation system according to the present embodiment will be described in detail with reference to FIG. 8.
FIG. 8 is a block diagram for illustrating an example of the hardware configuration of the control apparatus 500 that constitutes the medical observation system according to the present embodiment.

As illustrated in FIG. 8, the control apparatus 500 includes a CPU 501, a ROM 503, and a RAM 505. Furthermore, the control apparatus 500 also includes a host bus 507, a bridge 509, an external bus 511, an interface 513, an input apparatus 515, an output apparatus 517, and a storage apparatus 519. The control apparatus 500 may further include a drive 521, a connection port 523, and a communication apparatus 525.

The CPU 501 functions as an arithmetic processing apparatus and a control apparatus, and controls the overall operation or a part of the operation of the control apparatus 500 according to various programs recorded in the ROM 503, the RAM 505, the storage apparatus 519, or a removable recording medium 527.

The ROM 503 stores programs, operation parameters, and the like used by the CPU 501. The RAM 505 primarily stores programs used by the CPU 501 and parameters and the like varying as appropriate during the execution of the programs. These components are connected with each other via the host bus 507 configured as an internal bus such as a CPU bus or the like. The respective configurations of the control unit 52 of the control apparatus 18 described with reference to FIG. 2 are realized by the CPU 501, for example.

The host bus 507 is connected to the external bus 511 such as a PCI (Peripheral Component Interconnect/Interface) bus via the bridge 509. The input apparatus 515, the output apparatus 517, the storage apparatus 519, the drive 521, the connection port 523, and the communication apparatus 525 are connected to the external bus 511 via the interface 513.

The input apparatus 515 is an operating unit operated by a user, such as, for example, a mouse, a keyboard, a touch panel, buttons, a switch, a lever, and a pedal. The input apparatus 515 may be a remote control unit (so-called a remote control) using, for example, infrared rays or other radio waves, or may be an externally connected apparatus 529 such as a mobile phone or a PDA conforming to the operation of the control apparatus 500.

For example, the input apparatus 515 generates an input signal on the basis of, for example, information input by a user using the above-described operating unit, and is configured as an input control circuit for outputting the input signal to the CPU 501.
The user can input various kinds of data to the control apparatus 500 and can instruct the control apparatus 500 to perform processing by operating the input apparatus 515.

The output apparatus 517 is configured as an apparatus capable of visually or audibly notifying the user of acquired information. Specifically, the output apparatus 517 include a display apparatus such as a CRT display apparatus, a liquid crystal display apparatus, a plasma display apparatus, an EL display apparatus, and lamps, an audio output apparatus such as a speaker and a headphone, a printer, and the like.

For example, the output apparatus 517 outputs a result obtained by various kinds of processing performed by the control apparatus 500. Specifically, the display apparatus displays the result obtained by various kinds of processing performed by the control apparatus 500 in the form of text or images. On the other hand, the audio output apparatus converts an audio signal such as reproduced audio data and acoustic data into an analog signal, and outputs the analog signal. The light source apparatus 12 and the display apparatus 16 described with reference to FIG. 2 are realized by the output apparatus 517, for example.

The storage apparatus 519 is an apparatus for storing data configured as an example of a storage unit of the control apparatus 500. The storage apparatus 519 is configured as, for example, a magnetic storage device such as an HDD (Hard Disk Drive), a semiconductor storage device, an optical storage device, or a magneto-optical storage device. The storage apparatus 519 stores programs to be executed by the CPU 501, various kinds of data, and the like.

The drive 521 is a reader/writer for recording medium, and is embedded in the control apparatus 500 or attached externally thereto. The drive 521 reads information recorded in the attached removable recording medium 527 such as a magnetic disk, an optical disc, a magneto-optical disk, or a semiconductor memory, and outputs the read information to the RAM 505. Furthermore, the drive 521 can write data to the attached removable recording medium 527 such as a magnetic disk, an optical disc, a magneto-optical disk, or a semiconductor memory.

The removable recording medium 527 is, for example, a DVD medium, an HD-DVD medium, or a Blu-ray (registered trademark) medium. The removable recording medium 527 may be a CompactFlash (registered trademark), a flash memory, an SD (Secure Digital) memory card, or the like. Alternatively, the removable recording medium 527 may be, for example, an IC (Integrated Circuit) card equipped with a non-contact IC chip or an electronic appliance.

The connection port 523 is a port for directly connecting the externally connected apparatus 529 to the control apparatus 500. Examples of the connection port 523 include a USB (Universal Serial Bus) port, an IEEE1394 port, a SCSI (Small Computer System Interface) port, and the like. Other examples of the connection port 523 include an RS-232C port, an optical audio terminal, an HDMI (registered trademark) (High-Definition Multimedia Interface) port, and the like. By connecting the externally connected apparatus 529 to the connection port 523, the control apparatus 500 obtains various kinds of data directly from the externally connected apparatus 529 and provides various kinds of data to the externally connected apparatus 529.

The communication apparatus 525 is a communication interface configured as, for example, a communication device for connecting to a communication network 531. The communication apparatus 525 is, for example, a wired or wireless LAN (Local Area Network), Bluetooth (registered trademark), a communication card for WUSB (Wireless USB), or the like. Alternatively, the communication apparatus 525 may be a router for optical communication, a router for ADSL (Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line), a modem for various communications, or the like.

The communication apparatus 525 can transmit and receive signals and the like in accordance with a predetermined protocol such as TCP/IP to and from the Internet and other communication apparatuses, for example. The communication network 531 connected to the communication apparatus 525 is configured as a network and the like, which is connected via wire or wirelessly. The communication network 531 may be, for example, the Internet and a home LAN and may be a communication network that performs infrared communication, radio wave communication, or satellite communication.

Each of the components of the above-described control apparatus 500 may be configured using a general-purpose member, or may be configured as hardware dedicated to the function of each component. Accordingly, the hardware configuration to be used can be changed as appropriate according to the technical level at the time of carrying out the present embodiment.

A computer program for realizing each function of the control apparatus 500 that constitutes the medical observation system according to the present embodiment can be produced and be implemented on a personal computer or the like. Moreover, a computer-readable recording medium in which such a computer program is stored can be provided. The recording medium is, for example, a magnetic disk, an optical disc, a magneto-optical disk, a flash memory, or the like. In addition, the computer program may be delivered via a network, for example, without using a recording medium.

Note that an embodiment of the present disclosure is not limited to the above-described embodiment, but various alterations can be made within the scope not departing from the spirit of the present disclosure.
For example, the present disclosure may take the configuration of cloud computing in which one function is shared by a plurality of apparatuses via a network and is processed in cooperation.
Further, each step described in the above-described flowchart may be executed by one apparatus, and may be shared and executed by a plurality of apparatuses.

In addition, when one step includes a plurality of processes, the plurality of processes included in the one step may be executed by one apparatus, and may be shared and executed by a plurality of apparatuses.
